title: How many Chevrolet Bolt EV's will be sold between January and June 2018?
preds:
6,775 sold with only 1 month left to go.
https://insideevs.com/monthly-plug-in-sales-scorecard/
6775 with May's numbers. 3225 in a month isn't going to happen.

Excerpts from Inside EV's May report. "It has been an interesting year for electric vehicle sales with a lackluster January, the longest reporting holdup ever in February, and a record-breaking March. April also landed in the five-spot for all-time EV sales, which brings us to May. May easily secured a spot in the top five early on." You would think the rising tide of EV sales would positively impact the Bolt, but if the estimated sales numbers are to be believed, it has not. GM decided at the end of the 1st quarter 2018 that it will switch from monthly sales reporting and only release numbers at the close of each quarter. So, it will be July before we have a solid handle on Chevrolet Bolt sales numbers. The report goes on to say, "we see Bolt deliveries down at the moment, with Volt sales ramping up. This is all related to the situation with inventory. GM has upped production and inventory of its aging plug-in while beginning to reduce Bolt allocations." With Tesla's Model 3 production ramping up, The Bolt, which starts at $37K and goes 238 miles on a charge, is competing with the elegant Model 3 which starts at $35,000 and can go as much as 300 miles between plugins. Also, according to GM spokesperson Jim Cain, "Bolt sales fell due to lack of inventory." With 5 of 6 months worth of data in, the sales numbers for June would need to be to jump by 186% over May's to get to 10,000 units sold for the first six months of 2018 This is highly unlikely...
They'd need a record month to hit 10k, and that's not the recent trend.
6775 so far this year with only one month to go.

Even less likely given latest numbers from here: https://insideevs.com/monthly-plug-in-sales-scorecard/ My lack of absolute certainty accounts for mainly uncertainty in the reported numbers as well as the small chances of a major ramp (would have to be 3225 from just above 1k in the last couple of months)
I wish I could double down...  They are 3225 short of hitting 10,000 with one month to go. Their record highest month was 3227 while averaging just 1355 per month this year.
Dropping much lower due to low sales volumes. The numbers of Bolt's would have to dramatically increase this month and next to get over 10,000.

WoC0.71  Was way too optimistic (25k! LOL) at start. Maybe the BMW i3 is a good lease deal, stealing sales away. Seems like they may only get to around 8k at most.  Perhaps it's the leading indicator of recession coming. Car sales are way down. Despite full employment, it's a bit odd, so it's certainly turning soon.
I believe the hype is bigger than the demand. I do not see any in the fourth largest city in the US.

as per the many negative forecasts I am getting very pessimistic on my previous overly optimistic view. 
I judge they will not beat the 10k hurdle.

GM has publicly stated that it will no longer release monthly sales results for the U.S. Instead, the automaker will move to a quarterly release schedule - so the April number from Inside EV's is an estimate. So my estimate is based on another estimate - this just feels wonky!
GM needs to sell 2,200 Bolt EV's a month for the next two months to get over 10,000. This looks less and less likely to happen (even though they averaged over 2,600 per month the last half of 2017.
The Bolt EV still qualifies for government incentives, including up to $7,500 in Federal income tax credits and (select) state rebates. There have been Increases in gas prices over the last several months while competitor TESLA is unable to meet production goals. and yet the April sales estimate fell by 28% compared to last month.
The April 2018 seasonality factor is less than 1 and finance rates on 5-year consumer loans from banks for new cars are up from just over 4% to close to 5% over the last 6 months. This may be contributing to the estimated slowdown in sales.
Irrespective of the reasons why and barring another oil embargo, I now feel confident that less than 10,000 Chevrolet Bolt EV's will be sold between January and June 2018.

Meh.  Some time ago I  made a long post about how GM production line was 2500 per month, and how last year they had a huge inventory to move out, so they made incentives.  This year they didn't have the inventory back log; they had ceased all financing options.  Additionally,  no new model for 2018.  And a new competitor in the neo with better range, and newer styling. But  neither my post nor my forecast made it.  LOL.  Oh well.  GM loses 7-9,K per car.    And that picture does not get any better, any time soon, with the 7K incentives dropping out.  Thinking strategically here for a minute - Tesla needs to bet the farm on EV's.    GM doesn't.  Being the #2 manufacturer of EV's in the US is probably good enough.     Good enough to stay in the game, if it takes off; good enough to stay abreast of technology.  But fundamentally, the range of the EV's  isn't good enough, the recharge times isn't good enough.  The price isn't good enough.  The recharge infrastructure isn't in place. Barra has a reputation for watching the bottom line.   And I think she's played this exactly right.    Keep GM in the game.   Get enough buzz to keep people interested.    As I said in a previous post, I think the market for battery cards is not big (yet?); Tesla and tesla reservations are getting most of em.   7K per car is a lot of loss.   OTOH, idling a production line also involves loss.      So I could see GM putting incentive on cars to move them.  BTW Barra is pretty confident that congress is going to extend the tax credit.  Prognosticating this is going to get more interesting since GM has announced they're not going to do monthly totals any more...  Interestingly  the Volt sold more cars than the bolt - the volt had incentives, which points to just how sensitive consumers are to sales. TLDR if they sell at last year's pace - they only hit 8900.  Problem is - they're not.    No incentives, and interest rates going up.... downgrading for now..

5650 sold and 2/3 through forecasting period. Some latency in reporting? Cooler Spring? Thought there’d be more uptake given Tesla 3. Regardless, lowering forecast despite Bolt getting decent reviews etc
April was disastrous...  SO disastrous that it reversed a lot of trends.
Lowering on new numbers for April coming significantly below expectations.
1275 for April. Brings monthly average down to 1412.5 for this year. Would need 2175 May and June to reach 10,000. There were only more than 2100 sold in a month last year Sep - Dec.

Bolt sales in March were only 978, according to https://insideevs.com/march-2017-plug-electric-vehicle-sales-report-card/, but 1,774  according to Chevrolet as reported in https://electrek.co/2018/04/03/chevy-bolt-ev-sales-q1-production-increase/.

Revising after further research. Last year's average was just over 2,000 (https://electrek.co/2018/04/03/chevy-bolt-ev-sales-q1-production-increase/). The drop in January was at least partially a seasonal effect as well as customers supposedly taking advantage of the tax credit in December (https://electrek.co/2018/02/01/gm-chevy-bolt-ev-quarterly-sales-plunge/). Though the Bolt is seeing more competition this year, the lease option that exists for it is an important factor driving sales, I presume.  The more Bolts exist on the roads, the greater people's familiarity with the car, and the greater the sales. This feedback loop should contribute to some non-linearity in sales. An important question is when will the federal tax credit cease to apply. Apparently it is in force until a manufacturer has sold more than 200k cars (https://www.energy.gov/eere/electricvehicles/electric-vehicles-tax-credits-and-other-incentives). @shivadiva mentioned there'd be no more tax breaks this year, but I am not sure that's true (please correct me if I am wrong). As of November 2017, GM was about 40k away from that threshold as per this (http://evadoption.com/tesla-and-gm-should-each-reach-200000-in-total-us-ev-sales-by-q2-q3-2018-respectively). It seems that Bolt buyers will likely be able to take advantage of the tax credit through to Q2, but there is uncertainty around that.
Throwing my model out and trying reality for a bit.
4375 as of end of March. Might be close between 1st and 2nd buckets.
With Tesla not doing so great, perhaps more people will buy Bolts.
Reducing my >15k bin in favor of 10-15k, as on further reflection I do not expect demand and/or supply ramp ups to be too dramatic even if they happen.

4375 in 3 months. Starting to think it will be closer to 10 000 units (previously thinking 9 000) given release in additional states and GM skill in ramping up. I’ve never seen anything official about cannibalizing Tesla Model 3 sales (Less cachet in GM) but maybe some will?

https://electrek.co/2018/03/07/gm-increasing-chevy-bolt-ev-production/
They were moving 3,000/mo at the end of 2017, making 18,000 in the first
six months of 2018 seem reasonable, but then what to make of the drop 
from Dec '17 to Jan '18? (Tax benefit change?)  Maybe February's year on year
gain of just less than 50% growth will hold.  I'm probably overly hopeful on
the upside, but then, gas prices are up the past few weeks.
Basing this on a loose extrapolation of the trend up to March 2018 on InsideEV.
March sales indicate a growing sales increment. May and June should be solid months.
Based on the numbers between January and March (4,375).

4375 (1177,1424,1774) April 2017 was a dip month. So on trend would be <10000 but 8500+? Was 23k total last year for Bolt EV. 1H2017 was 7592 (1162, 952, 978, 1292, 1566, 1642) and 2017Jan-Mar was 3092. So a 29.3% rise (or -1.3, +33.1,  +44.9 avg 25%) So even a 30% increase on 2017 still won't get it over 10k. A huge majority of car sales come in the 2nd half of the year. So it would require a 30k annual to get over 10k or a 30+ percent from 2017.  What is the production numbers from Chevy? It's hard enough guessing the Tesla 3 Question here. Maybe if they're making more than 3000 a month they'll do a clearance sale before June?  11004, 12375, 18542, 13367, 17046 (Jan-Jun 2017)
12049, 16845, 26373  (Jan-Mar 2018) much of it from #1 the Tesla Model 3.
Half way numbers are now available.
Shifting heavily lower now that I've seen three months of sales numbers.

Updating the forecast based on March's Chevy Bolt sales of 1,774 units. The increase in sales in 2018 has been over 20 percent per month. This is primarily due to the following: Motor Trend's 2017 EV Car of the Year award
Tesla's Model 3 falling short of production targets
And 2018 seeing continued momentum in new EV's coming to market, the expansion of charging networks, and advances in battery technology. Therefore as we head into the backstretch with three more months of data to go, I am raising the forecast probability of selling between 10,001 & 15,000 to 2/3 and dropping the chance of anything above that to about 1 in 6. There remains about a 1 in 5 chance that sales fall to under 10,000 but barring a significant drop in oil prices or a Bolt recall, that likelihood diminishes with each new data point.
Linear extrapolation yields approximately 8,200 in sales by end of June. However, sales in 2018 are outpacing sales of 2017 at the same time.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-autos-gm/gm-will-stop-reporting-monthly-u-s-vehicle-sales-idUSKCN1HA0C9
With no monthly updates this one will get trickier.  One gathers there will be no interim report between end of March and closing of the Q.  Should be able to derive March sales by simple subtraction once the Q1 report comes out, but after that, who knows?  Good luck.
based on previous years sales and competition from other emerging EV makers.

https://electrek.co/2018/03/01/gm-cant-take-advantage-tesla-model-3-delays-chevy-bolt-ev/
Sales for Jan 1177 
Sales for feb 1424 
To reach 10k bin by July they need 10k - 2,601= 7399/5 = 1480 per month which is doable I guess. 
Much slower than anticipated 
Range 1100 to 1500/ month, or 6900 to 9000. Maybe able to ratchet up above 1500. Plus 5000 sales to South Korea - not a binding agreement though so on the higher end range might be 12, 000 to 14,000 I’m weighting the lower end due to North American market has largest impact on sales and now past year-end so no more tax breaks to buy; sales in all EV generally lower this year. Do Expect a sales push in time for inclusion and reporting in q2 financials https://electrek.co/2018/03/01/gm-cant-take-advantage-tesla-model-3-delays-chevy-bolt-ev/

Recent articles indicate large investments, by major auto makers for 2020 mass market electric vehicles.  It seems that GM is not interested in maximizing the current sales of the Bolt.  The flood of Mas produced EV may start in the 2020-2022 timeframe. From: https://www.ft.com/content/25f947da-1718-11e8-9e9c-25c814761640:
Snow storms are not good times to think about EV's, rachet down my estimate accordingly

Dateline  3-1-2018 GM still can’t take advantage of Tesla Model 3 delays with its Chevy Bolt EV, sales down to 1,400 units in the US  -- https://electrek.co/2018/03/01/gm-cant-take-advantage-tesla-model-3-delays-chevy-bolt-ev/ Thank you, @shivadiva at http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/713438

https://electrek.co/2018/03/01/gm-cant-take-advantage-tesla-model-3-delays-chevy-bolt-ev/
Sales for Jan 1177 
Sales for feb 1424 
To reach 10k bin by July they need 10k - 2,601= 7399/5 = 1480 per month which is doable I guess.
Much slower than anticipated
Range 1100 to 1500/ month, or 6900 to 9000. Maybe able to ratchet up above 1500. Plus 5000 sales to South Korea - not a binding agreement though so on the higher end range might be 12, 000 to 14,000  I’m weighting the lower end due to North American market has largest impact on sales and now past year-end so no more tax breaks to buy; sales in all EV generally lower this year. Do Expect a sales push in time for inclusion and reporting  in q2 financials https://electrek.co/2018/03/01/gm-cant-take-advantage-tesla-model-3-delays-chevy-bolt-ev/

Bolt sales were up 49% year over year in Feb. 
Assume remaining months of 1H2018 sales are double last year's.
Nobody buys an EV during a snowstorm. 
If you are tired of waiting for your model 3, lease a Bolt.
Is there a way to request a new question of this from Mack Inst.? I'd like a FY2018 one, ending say December 1st. Sick of those questions that end AFTER the result is known!
Total is still only 2501, too few updates!

Only 6 more states will be able to order in the next few months and the current orders are around 120/state/mo. Without a big campaign or buyer incentive, I don't see how they will sell more than 1000-2000/mo for the next month which would only be another 8,000 on top of the 1900 that have sold through Feb.

Chevy Bolt sales dropped dramatically in January with the ending of incentives.  GM will have to re-introduce incentives in order to push sales.  The continued paucity of charging stations will reduce the attractiveness of the Bolt as anything but an around-home-base car

Presuming the question means until the end of june:  ( I do so hate imprecise questions)
1.  Sales in 2017 were just over 8k units, over the same time period.
2.   Year over year sales for Jan/Feb averaged +14.5%
3.  While the overall market for cars is expectected to be down 2%, electric/hybrid sales are expected to be up 2%.
4.   GM committed to increasing production later this year - which isn't worth anything except to show that it sees continued interest in the bolt.  https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/07/mary-barra-gm-ceraweek-chevy-bolt.html
5.   To the negative, the bolt didn't get  afacelift his model year.  Honda's new model makes an appearance; generally has better range and better interior.   Model 3 will continue to be a no show.
6.  Dollar exchange rates will penalize toyota/honda.   Rust belt workers will be more interested in American products; electric car sales will not be cannibalized by used cars sales the way IC car sales will be.

GM thinking of production ramp later this year.
source:https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/07/mary-barra-gm-ceraweek-chevy-bolt.html
until that happens, don't think significant pickup in sales is in the cards.
I have a strong interest in electric cars and see sales data being consistent with the end of last year

23k last year and on trend to easily beat it this year (Jan and Feb are higher than in 2018), so for Jan to Jun it should easily get to 10k or so. The second half has much higher sales with December being the biggest month. Wish there was another question to guess the annual sales too.
Slower sales as market  adjusts to the new technology.

Looking at the published February sales numbers my initial forecast was too high. Again without the benefit of much historical data, this is going to be a tough forecast. The expected bump in sales from Consumer Reports giving the Bolt top marks and Motor Trend bestowing Bolt with the EV of the Year award was smaller than I expected. While the increase in sales from January was a solid 21 percent, given January, February, November, and December look to be the slowest sales months based on their Federal Reserve seasonal factor numbers, I've revised my forecast down. With the benefit of two more data points (Jan & Feb sales data), the expected growth in units demanded based on the 6 month moving average of units sold dropped by over 4 percent - likely reflecting the winter doldrums. This reduced the expected total number sold to about $14,300. Anything can happen between now and June from a massive recall to a large spike in gas prices which is a reason for the "shotgun approach" to the probabilities. (Another is the mean absolute % error being so big.) Let's see if my new improved calculations hold up when the actual March sales numberis releasd in Early April. Stay tuned!
January and February coming in below expectations.  Making adjustments accordingly.
The Bolt's two-month total for 2018 does not support the probability that Chevrolet will reach sales of 10,000 units.

Last year Chevy sold 23297 Bolt EV's. Sales increased almost linearly (m=280.9). Thus I suspect that Bolt sales will continue growing at a similar rate of 281 cars/month. Adding up Jan+Feb production and the projected next 4 months comes out to 12349 cars. Chevy owners will not be subjected to a reduction of their $7500 federal tax credit for cars bought this year (but Tesla and GM owners might). I also do not foresee additional local & state incentives in the near future to further stimulate EV sales. Nor do I see demand suddenly increasing since gas prices remain fairly low & stable. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/11/business/electric-vehicles-taxes-tesla-gm.html

The US has not really woken up on this issue yet and there is still space for several players in the market.  The mass production potential of GM is formidable, however, the Bolt cannot satisfy a market for an upper-end, quality vehicle.  Nonetheless, the Bolt may appeal to many average consumers who are ready to take the plunge.  Also, I would consider the not so obvious agents of change such as Uber drivers, delivery drivers who use their own vehicles.  When the US wakes up and realizes that the short-haul market is ripe for savings in fuel, things may start to change.  One of the principle drivers will be the availability of charging stations.  GM could use its influence to promote charging station growth which would float the entire industry.  Tesla has taken the lead with its network of Superchargers​.
Cost and range anxiety will minimise sales.
2601 in Jan and Feb (1177 + 1424). sales may pick up in Spring but slower than I was expecting. Changing forecast (lower) as a result.

January sales were 1,177 units. Expect sales of around 1,200 per month through June with no significant supply side inducements or additional tax incentives, reaching some 7,200 units by deadline. Maybe spring will enliven sales a bit. To top 10,000 units current monthly sales must increase by more  than 20% on average, and fast. That’s is not very likely.
GM is a me too company, which is OK in old heavy metal industry, but disastrous in tech.
Based in the historical sales of Electric Vehicles in the USA and assuming the bolt will capture about one third of the electrical vehicle market.

I'm updating my forecast based on poor January numbers. I'll be curious what comes out in a few days with February. This article states that there are significantly fewer incentives for the 2018 car -- would love additional sources to state this as the cause for the 3x decrease in sales between end of 2017 and 2018. https://www.fool.com/investing/2018/02/02/chevrolet-bolt-us-sales-january-2018.aspx
No updates for this years model. Very slow start in Jan.

adjusting on quick review of articles below to be reviewed in more depth later. https://cleantechnica.com/2017/05/09/5-months-chevrolet-bolt-sales-numbers-tell-us-far/
https://cleantechnica.com/2018/01/11/2017-electric-car-sales-projections-revisited-2018-projections/

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-autos-ratings/chevrolet-bolt-wins-top-green-car-from-consumer-reports-idUSKCN1G62FF
Can't hurt.  Inching up a bit more.

It’s not clear to me how much production has ramped up but number of states that can purchase (ar dealerships) has increased. Dec 2017 California and Oregon deliveries. By April dealerships in 8 states will be taking delivery. So possible bridge of 15000 but off to a slow start (1177 in January). Will be interesting to see Feb sales data (available in 5 states).

GM only moved 1177 in January. Production is picking up but still can’t meet demand - LG may still be behind in ramping up. Will be interesting to see Feb numbers and updated forecast. Thinking 15000 or slightly over will be sweet spot. As per others, some Tesla 3 prospects may shift to GM given Tesla delivery delays.
Looks like they are selling about 3000 per month.  Forecast for car sales generally are down for 2018.  Under 20000 is a real possibility.
GM is not fully involved with selling electric cars and dealers have no incentive to sell them since they make majority of their income/ profit from service and electric cars have no service needs

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-model3-bolt/tesla-delays-tax-credit-concerns-spur-sales-of-chevy-bolts-idUSKCN1G02F3 "GM dealers in California, the top U.S. market for electric vehicles, say brisk demand for Bolts is driven in part by frustrated Tesla buyers who are afraid they will lose a $7,500 electric vehicle tax credit if they wait. The tax credit drops in value and eventually disappears once Tesla sells 200,000 electric vehicles in the United States, which Edmunds analyst Jeremy Acevedo expects Tesla to hit by the fall.  Chevrolet dealer Yev Kaplinskiy said his dealership located between San Francisco and Silicon Valley sold 15 Bolts last weekend, after Tesla’s latest delay. "

This is a challenging estimate due to the lack of historical data, the Chevy Bolt was introduced in December 2016. In a nutshell, I took the monthly sales data and deseasonalized it using 'Federal Reserve Seasonal Factors for Motor Vehicle Sales'. I then took a 5-month moving average of the sales figures and ran some simple formulas to solve for units of demand and deviation from that demand. Applying a growth formula for the remaining 5 months 'til June 2018 (January's sales #'s are already available) and backed out the seasonal factors or "reseasonalized" (totally made that up) and totaled the estimates. The probability estimates are normal distribution percentages one and two standard deviations from the mean. I will revisit this each month and revise and refine my forecast along the way.

These are going to be some of the most affordable electric vehicles based on the sale of 21000 total electric vehicles in September of 2017 I think it's very possible that it will reach a number even higher than laid out in these options maybe even 40,000 by then.
These vehicles are the worst driving experience I have ever had.  I just do not think there are very many people out there who think they are.

January: 1177 sales. 
Total sales in Jan-June last year around 7500. 
Looking at the data from the Volt, we should expect around 40% of sales being made in the first half of the year. 
Also, the last three months of the year seem to usually account for more than third of the yearly sales. Projecting   
the 9000 sold units from the last three months of 2017 (when the model was available nationwide) upwards, we get an expected amount of a bit above 27000. This yields around 11000 sales in the relevant time frame, with a tendency to slightly understimate. However, the data from january looks comparable to last year, indicating, that the model might be too optimistic.
Chevy Bolt is well made by a trusted domestic manufacturer. Tax incentives will disappear, but many will consider this vehicle for social proof purposes regardless.
Electric cars are terrible. Fuel cell vehicles are the future.

Dropping significantly lower because I was basing my forecast on the monthly change from 2017. However, January sales figures of 1,177 were way lower than the trend in 2017 and looking back through the years sales were much lower in the first half of the year than in the second.
I waited for the January sales data to update my forecast. Sales for this car, and probably most electric cars, appear volatile.

Based on January sales, I'm thinking the final number will probably be somewhere between 17,000 and 25,000, so I've adjusted my forecast accordingly.   I'm putting a micro-forecast for February sales numbers of 2,803.  @cmeinel, @praedico, and @Guydreaux, as well as anyone else are welcome to join in and make a February forecast at no extra charge.

7592 were sold 6 months ago last year, base rate.
https://electrek.co/2018/02/01/gm-chevy-bolt-ev-quarterly-sales-plunge/ Compared to a running tally, Jan 1177 evs sold.
GM sold around 20.000 in the US last year. They should do better this year

Total for January 2018: 1177.
That is similar to last year (1162).
Last year's Jan-Jun total was 7592.
Reduced due to low sales numbers in January
Loss of tax credit really hurts sales.
The vehicle sold out the production run of 30K with it being available for less than the entire year. Selling more than 30,000 should not be a difficult goal to reach.
Production/sales seem to be uptick. Potential hit from weather in NorthEast but believe 2500 likely base month with more upside than down. Looking forward to stats on Feb 1.
Responding to @shivadiva's base rate calculations and projections thereon. Thank you, great work. http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/678610
People want to buy, but the people interested in buying are also the ones who don't trust the current political climate, so they are less likely to make investments like this.

https://insideevs.com/december-2017-plugin-electric-vehicle-sales-report-card/ growth is 18% 2016-2017, with some outlier numbers around January 2017 so a range of 13%  to 18% (excludes Dec 2016 and jan 2017). Growth likely so mid-range picked 16% for total 1/2 year sales of 13477
Sales are on track to be around 18,000, but there has been considerable sales growth.  Tesla has been slow to get the model 3 out, which may help the Bolt.  The tax credit remains for now.
December Bolt 3,227. Some tax credit still in place. Looks to be ramping up while Tesla can not deliver as promised. But I would think no more than 4,000 per month during these slow Winter months.

GM to sell 5,000 Bolts to SKorea. Although these are not likely to count as US sales, it is an indication that production is likely to increase in 2018.
https://electrek.co/2018/01/16/gm-chevy-bolt-ev-south-korea/
2017 sales and expected trends in oil prices.

Range is still the deciding factor. Once EV ranges exceed 500 miles and with quick charging or interchangeable charged batteries are available, the vehicles will take off in the market. A major limitation is that manufacturers are NOT designing interchangeable charging stations or swappable batteries and until this happens, EVs will be restricted to commuter cars. EV sales in the US for all manufacturers will not exceed 250,000 per year until after 2020. "By year-end there were about 30 different EV offerings, with total sales of 159,139 vehicles. Five different models sold at least 10,000 units in 2016: Tesla Model S, Tesla Model X, Chevrolet Volt, Nissan Leaf, and Ford Fusion Energi."  https://www.forbes.com/sites/rrapier/2017/02/05/u-s-electric-vehicle-sales-soared-in-2016/#3bd83626217f
There are plenty of people with money that are interested enough in this.
Moving ten points higher because sales seems increase by about 200 per month. At that rate I think we see sales at around 23,000 in total.
I am expecting GM to sell close to 2,100 units per month. The question is, can GM keep up with delivery orders.

Total for July - December 2017 is: 15,705.
Minimum estimate for Jan - June 2018 is: 10,500.
The problem is the availability of convenient charging stations until the are available everywhere so we can travel long distances it will not be a popular item to buy
sales goal of 30 k per year, so 15 k base for 6 months. already hitting 3,000 a month so 18 k is reasonable. production capability could limit anything above 20k

Monthly sales are increasing reliably, and many of the states where this machine will be available early next year are either large or electrically inclined or both  I think the feds have kept some of their incentives--somebody must have told the Prez these vehicles burn coal--and several states have kept theirs.  Coming up some, but probably not enough.

3227 sold in December  and 23297 for the year just ended. Likely 2500-3000/month 
(green carreports.com). Oil at $60and likely steady. Go low and still likely at 15000
I don't know how many were sold in 2017 , but I don't see that much increase in liberals this year.
I believe the new tax law negatively impacts green car incentives.
They can expect high demand. The public at large is demanding the product even when the auto producers and States are impeding it.
Overall sales for 2017 will exceed 20k units.    If trends continue with increasing popularity of evs, I expect the trend will accelerate.
Basing it on past sales and forecasts.
Shifting a little higher because monthly totals keep increasing.

Now looking like there is a good chance the energy tax credit will stay in the Republican tax bill:  https://electrek.co/2017/12/13/electric-vehicle-tax-credit-safe-final-us-tax-bill/.  If the credit does remain available, my projection will go back up about 25,000 based on my model.  (I love saying 'my model'.  It makes me sound so Nate Silverish.) Splitting the difference now and moving my projections up.
Shifting a little higher because sales rise by a little each quarter and I expect to see them around 18,000-19,000 for the first six months of the year.
A shout out to @WhatCouldHappen for this analysis: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/630244

When it became clear there was a pretty good chance the $7500 federal tax credit would be lost, I cut my projection and have let this slide since then.  With the November sales figures out, I've taken another look at the numbers: 1)  This year, Bolt sales have been increasing at an average rate of 11.24%/month. I think the rate will drop as the actual numbers go up.  (It was 17% at the end of September.)  If we call it at an average of 5%/month increase through next June, we're looking at a projection of 22,400. 2)  I'm using the Chevy Volt, a hybrid introduced in December of 2010, as a model.  When comparing 2011 Volt sales to the first 6 months of 2012, you can project Bolt sales of between 24,386 to 31,454 next year thru June, depending on which time periods you would like to use. I've given the above projections different weighting and came up with an average projection of 25,160...But that doesn't account for any loss of sales resulting from the repeal of the federal tax credit, which is very difficult to predict.   My back of the envelope estimate of that loss is 20% which brings me down to 20,128, and I've adjusted my forecast accordingly.

Sales have been steadily increasing lately now that the Bolt is on sale nationwide. My guess is that they stay around 3K per month through the first quarter of 2018, with high upside risk. Based on strong media reports, weak Tesla performance, and demand so far, looks like low downside risk for the Bolt in the first half of 2018.

November sales were more than I expected. So the numbers for the second half of this year are: 1971 (July) + 2107 (Aug) + 2631 (Sept) + 2781 (Oct) + 2987 (Nov) + 4050 (Dec estimate) = 16,527. Two-thirds of that is 11,083. So that's my minimum estimate for Jan-Jun 2018. EV sales are trending upwards, so it will be a little more next year.

7592 was the number this year. Bolt was not available in all states until September 2017, but may not matter, as New York and California were included. Sept and Oct numbers don't look all that spectacular.  Number sold in first half of year tends to be about 2/3 number sold in last half of year, maybe a little more. I'm expecting a 30-40% bump in December. So number for second half of 2017 expected to be: 1971 (July) + 2107 (Aug) + 2631 (Sept) + 2781 (Oct) + 2706 (Nov estimate) + 3654 (Dec estimate) = 15,850. Two-thirds of that would be 10,620. Estimate for Jan-Jun 2018.

It will be interesting to see how much of a surge there will be in November and December based on the significant possibility (60%?) of the loss of the $7500 tax credit on purchases after Dec. 31.   Even if the credit isn't eliminated, a surge would represent sales that would have happened in 2018 which will now be moved to 2017, and to complicate matters, Tesla drivers on the wait list may drop out to purchase a Bolt today to obtain the tax credit:  ( http://www.scpr.org/news/2017/11/08/77522/tax-plan-could-pump-the-brakes-on-ca-s-electric-ca/ ) If the credit elimination does go through, it wouldn't be unreasonable to forecast little or no increase in sales over the first six months of 2017. (7,592)   For now, I'm splitting the difference between the two scenarios.

Elements I thought about:
This isn't normally distributed. There are greater odds for less than 10,000 because of a recall, or other large event resulting in short-term slowdown.
On the supply side it seems difficult for more than 25,000 to be sold in 6 months (per @cmeinel)
The rest of the forecast is based on me thinking that a value around 18-19k is in line with growth, with decent potential for the various factors (tax-credit, macro economics, large corporate/government purchase agreement) driving it higher or lower. 
Answers I'd like to know:
What is the historic seasonality of auto sales?
Do any large states have EV policies (rebates for cars or charging stations) taking place on January 1, 2018?

Trouble in Muskland may well mean higher sales for Chevy Bolt. I get the feeling that Elon Musk is blaming poor production on the need for him to help rescue Puerto Rico's electrical grid  is a dog ate my homework story. I suspect he can walk and chew gum at the same time; likewise, if his electric vehicle business was being run by competent executives, it should be possible to not have to drain away expertise from electric vehicles in order to build a better electrical grid for Puerto Rico. Dateline 10-6-2017 Resources are being diverted to address the bottlenecks holding back the Model 3, Musk wrote in a tweet Friday. He’s also delaying the semi unveiling to Nov. 16 because Tesla is prioritizing efforts to increase battery output for Puerto Rico, which has sought the company’s help to restore power following Hurricane Maria. Tesla built only 260 Model 3 sedans during the third quarter, less than a fifth of its 1,500-unit forecast. The company has offered scant detail about the problems it’s having producing the mission-critical car that starts at $35,000, roughly half the cost of the least expensive Model S sedan. A delayed ramp up risks the ire of some of the almost half a million reservation holders who started paying $1,000 deposits early last year. -- https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-06/tesla-delays-semi-unveiling-on-model-3-bottlenecks-puerto-rico

Bolts are available in all states by September. 2017 January through June, they were only available from 7 to 18 states, though these included NY and CA. Number sold for January-June 2017 was 7592. Sales numbers pick up in later months of the year. August 2017 number is 2107.  My inclination is to multiply the 2107 by 6 months (12,642). I expect Jan-June to not do as well as July-August, but I am considering the greater of number of states where the car will be available compared to this year. I will stick with that until I have some idea of how the Bolt is selling after it enjoys wider availability. Of course, EVs are growing in popularity, but the Bolt will be in competition with the Tesla Model 3.

Initial forecast/reactions. As other posters have mentioned, with Bolt EV's upward trend and very positive 2017 YTD results, I don't see a large chance of Chevy selling < 10k units in 1H2018. However, as more units hit the roads, there is still a likelihood that there are unforeseen issues with the cars (structural issues, battery fires, issues with autonomous driving) that would cause sales to drop off.
News about the Bolt autonomous vehicle with Cruise Automation may provide a ceiling for purchases now, since the AV will need more accessories and hardware.

For those looking for models, I would offer the Chevrolet Volt, a hybrid introduced in December of 2010.  The first six months of 2012 sales increased over the first six month of 2011 sales by 221%.    The Honda Fit, introduced in 2006, increased sales by 102% in 2007.  (I could only find annual figures as opposed to month to month.)  Using those two models, I extrapolated a range of 15,335 to 24,730 for the Bolt.  I'll be keeping track of the monthly figures to compare them to the Volt Hybrid sales of 2011.

Headlines: Sales Jan. through Aug. 2017: 11,670.  Aug. sales: 2,052. There now are currently 1235 Bolt EV–certified stores in the United States, ~40% of the 3000 U.S. Chevy outlets. Analysis: It only is possible to buy the Bolt via a certified Chevy dealer. The number of such dealerships has been increasing rapidly.  Thus with the dealership bottleneck having widened, we can expect higher average monthly sales than what we have seen so far. Even a straight line projection disregarding increasing dealerships, we get 2017 sales of 17,505.  In the worst case, assuming average monthly sales of 1/12 of the projected 2017 sales, and presuming no black swan, Jan. -- June 2018 sales would be at least 8,752. For a less pessimistic projection, assume Aug. sales levels continue through Jan. -- June 2018: 12, 312. Because of new dealerships and rising monthly sales, and in particular Aug. sales, I am zeroing out the less than 10K bin. Now for the top bin, production constraints are likely to hold through the forecast period. So it may not be possible to ramp up sales much beyond 2500/month. This gives a ceiling of ~ 15,000 -- 20,000. On the other hand, Aug. sales suggest that it may be worthwhile to immediately begin investing in higher production facilities. So I'm putting some probabilities int he top two bins for now. Sources:  Dateline Sept. 6, 2017 -- General Motors (NYSE:GM) said it delivered 2,052 Chevrolet Bolt EVs in the United States in August. It was the best month yet for the little electric crossover. ..Long story short: The Bolt may already be close to sales "success"
I strongly suspect that GM will be pleased if the Bolt can sustain about 2,500 sales a month -- pleased enough to accelerate its development of more electric models. (It may have already made that decision.)  It's possible the Bolt's sales will never go much beyond that level.. -- https://www.fool.com/investing/2017/09/06/how-far-can-sales-rise-for-general-motors-electric.aspx http://insideevs.com/monthly-plug-in-sales-scorecard/ Dateline Sept. 7, 2017 -- GM said that it sold 12,249 Bolt EVs between December 2016—when the first deliveries were made in California—and August 30, 2017. Of those, 11,670 were sold since the beginning of 2017. That puts it on pace to outsell the Nissan Leaf and every other affordable electric car—a quick surge to the top of the charts, considering that availability was limited to certain regions until just now, when the automaker has announced that Bolt is finally available nationwide. ..There are currently 1235 Bolt EV–certified stores in the United States, roughly 40 percent of the 3000 U.S. Chevy outlets..  ...it could be on track to pass 20,000 sales for the year. -- http://blog.caranddriver.com/chevrolet-bolt-ev-on-pace-to-outsell-every-electric-car-except-tesla-model-s/

No change in the forecast since this analysis isn't exactly news, but Motley Fool did a pretty good analysis suggesting that Chevy may see 2,500 per month as successful, which would put the 6-month total at around 15,000.   https://www.fool.com/investing/2017/09/06/how-far-can-sales-rise-for-general-motors-electric.aspx
Shifting down a little as the jump from July to August was less than I hoped.

Just taking Jul-Aug purchases and extrapolating to 6 months would put the number at 12,234.
     1971 sales in Jul, 2107 sales in Aug.  Since Jul/Aug typically make up 17-18% of total year, and Jan-Jun 48-50%, (https://www.edmunds.com/industry-center/data/sales.html and http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2012/10/usa-auto-industry-total-sales-figures.html) that would put estimated 2018 Jan-Jun sales at 11,327.  Depending on whether you extrapolate from July, Aug, or the two combined, and how you estimate those months share of total sales, the estimates will vary between 10,500 and 13,000.
Fleets will be wary, since the charging infrastructure may not be there to start and drivers may not trust it.  Probably fleets won't buy much in 2018, so I wouldn't expect that to change the overall sales numbers much.
Looks like they won't advertise very broadly (http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1111082_yes-ads-for-the-chevy-bolt-ev-electric-car-do-actually-exist-heres-one), so I wouldn't expect a big push from that. Why might it beat the ~11,327 estimates:
     Increased visibility from Model 3 release may broaden overall market.
     Exceptional reviews and word of mouth broadens overall market Why it might not beat the ~11,327 estimate:
     More of its potential buyers decide that waiting on a Tesla Model 3 is a better deal. As those begin to roll off the line, the similar price point may temp people to wait on the "better" brand.
     Poor Model 3 rollout might dampen enthusiasm for the overall market among potential buyers. Overall, I would put slightly more weight on it beating expectations.

My guess is that EV cars are only getting more popular, albeit slowly. Since Chevy sold just under 10,000 Bolts in the first half of this year that seems like a good baseline. Their customer will be dramatically bigger in the first half of next year (going from 18 to all states) so I think we see a increase, even though those first 18 states were probably the biggest markets for EV vehicles. Furthermore, sales have been steadily increasing, even in the face of added competition. I think next year we see similar slow but steady growth.
Chevy as a brand is fading, Tesla is hot, and oil prices will stay low.

If GM only produces 25-30k in 2018, then wouldn't this constrain sales to roughly 12-15k per six month period as high side? Am I missing something obvious? US historic sales show rise, but current best month extrapolated to first six months next year result in less than 10k, which seems to make under 10k more likely than I believe most are considering. Looking at competitive sales, 10-15k seems most likely.

As of the end of June, US sales totaled 6529. GM is only planning to produce 25,000 to 30,000 Bolts a year. Source: http://www.reuters.com/article/us-autos-gm-bolt-idUSKBN0L92VL20150205 So more than 25,000 seems unlikely. I'm giving it 5%. Given that after half a year, 6529 have been sold, 10,00 seems well nigh impossible. I'm giving it 2%. Sales are ramping up slowly, so I give 20,000 - 25,000 16%. Wild card: I haven't found foreign sales data. But by the dog that isn't barking theory (Sherlock Holmes), that suggests weak foreign sales. I'll revisit this question as the next monthly sales figures materialize. Comparison classes: In 2016, Nissan Leaf sales were about 17,000, the Chevrolet Volt 15,000, and the BMW i3 11,000. None of these has anything like the Bolt EV's 200-mile range. Source: http://www.businessinsider.com/2017-chevy-bolt-ev-sales-could-be-80k-2016-5 Dateline July 3, 2017 Albeit slowly, GM’s Chevy Bolt EV sales are still growing – reaching a new high of 1,642 units in the US last month. It brings the total delivered of the new all-electric vehicle in the US to 7,592 units since the beginning of the year and just over 8,000 since its launch in December 2016. In June, GM opened Chevy Bolt EV orders for approved dealerships nationwide, But that didn’t contribute to deliveries since the first shipment to the new approved dealerships are expected in August. At that point, we should have a better idea of the market for the Bolt EV. In the meantime, it’s still not clear if the vehicle is still production constraint or if it’s a demand issue. In certain markets where the vehicle is officially available, it can be difficult to get your hands on one, while in other markets, like California, there are decent inventories and some customers have been getting away with paying $25,000 after incentives due to discounts. Source: https://electrek.co/2017/07/03/gm-chevy-bolt-ev-sales-3/ Dateline June 9, 2017 ...now all authorized dealers can order the all-electric car. You can always check with your local dealers for inventory and see if you can find a deal. Source: 
 https://electrek.co/2017/06/09/gm-chevy-bolt-orders-nationwide-deliveries-august/ Dateline June 1, 2017  As we previously reported, GM has been struggling to ramp production and deliveries of the Chevy Bolt EV since its launch in December, but they now seem to have a good trend going over the past two months. GM’s Chevy Bolt EV deliveries last month rose to 1,566 units, which is still below the rate needed to achieve its target, but it’s still a significant increase. The increase last month can be explained by the vehicle reaching more states. As per GM’s own distribution plan, the Bolt EV is supposedly in dealerships in California, Oregon, Massachusetts, Maryland,  and Virginia since the beginning of the year. New York, New Jersey and Washington were added throughout the first quarter and deliveries in Connecticut, Maine, Rhode Island, Vermont, New Hampshire and Colorado started in May.
Source:  https://electrek.co/2017/06/01/gm-chevy-bolt-ev-sales-2/

They do seem to have a ramp up planned, though it is still unclear how much they wish to produce(@cmeinel) at a loss.
